results.title: Migration: the first week
results.creator_credit: David Corke, Ken J. Widdowson and Educational Media Australia
results.brief_description: In this film the Rata family are seen arriving in Australia and settling into a hostel. The problems encountered in their first week include finding employment, enrolling the children in school and child care centres and coping with the language barrier.
results.creator_credit_for_label: David Corke, Ken J. Widdowson and Educational Media Australia

results.title: Migration: the decision to migrate
results.creator_credit: David Corke, Ken J. Widdowson and Educational Media Australia
results.brief_description: The first of a three part program which traces a Finnish family from its initial decision to emigrate to Australia, probes their reactions to living in Australia, and finally explains why the family prepare to return to Finland after 18 months in Australia. This filmed interview looks at the lifestyle of the family in Finland and their reasons for migrating. Their reasons range from undisclosed personal considerations to the feeling that personal freedom and initiative have declined in Finland and that life in Australia will provide better opportunities for their children.

results.title: Migration: after eighteen months
results.creator_credit: David Corke, Ken J. Widdowson and Educational Media Australia
results.brief_description: This is the last film about the Rata family and their emigration from Finland to Australia. It looks at the occurrences of the 18 months stay and the reasons leading to the family’s decision to return home to Finland. It contrasts their expectations with the reality of living in Australia.
results.creator_credit_for_label: David Corke, Ken J. Widdowson and Educational Media Australia

results.title: How to make an American quilt
results.creator_credit: Jill Bilcock, Jocelyn Moorhouse, Midge Sanford, Sarah Pillsbury and Amblin Entertainment
results.brief_description: Winona Ryder shines in this deeply moving and touchingly funny story of a Berkeley graduate student Finn (Ryder) who spends the summer at the home of her sparring Grandmother (Anne Bancroft) and great aunt (Ellyn Burstyn). Their house is a quiet haven where she intends to finish her latest thesis and think over a marriage proposal. This beautifully filmed tale brings unbridled passion, true love, betrayal, joy and heartbreak vividly to life in a captivating cinematic tapestry that celebrates finding your way and following your heart. Based on the novel by Whitney Otto.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Jill Bilcock, Jocelyn Moorhouse, Midge Sanford, Sarah Pillsbury and Amblin Entertainment

results.title: Romeo and Juliet (Luhrmann)
results.creator_credit: Catherine Martin, Jill Bilcock, Baz Luhrmann, Gabriella Martinelli and Bazmark
results.brief_description: Baz Luhrmann, director of “Strictly Ballroom” tells the greatest love story of all time in our time. William Shakespeare’s classic tale of star-crossed lovers is set in Verona Beach; a violent modern city of guns, money and greed. In this opulent world of hate, rival gangs, and families at war Romeo and Juliet are ignited by the passion of forbidden first love and Verona Beach explodes. Shakespeare’s heart wrenching tale of doomed love is told with passion, beauty, wit and furious energy. It’s a film that will kick you in the heart.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Catherine Martin, Jill Bilcock, Baz Luhrmann, Gabriella Martinelli and Bazmark

results.title: Muriel's wedding (Captioned)
results.creator_credit: Jill Bilcock, P.J. Hogan, Jocelyn Moorhouse, Lynda House, Peter Szabo and Associates, Film Victoria and House and Moorhouse Films
results.brief_description: Muriel is a dag, an Abba maniac and out of place girl who would give anything to be like her bitchy friends. In her hunt to find Mr. Right in all the wrong places, Muriel takes a one-way ticket to freedom to find herself. A bitter-sweet and much acclaimed film which touches the essence of the themes of self-respect, identity and friendship. Toni Collette gives an inspired performance as Muriel and the supporting cast includes Bill Hunter, Sophie Lee, Jeanie Drynan and Rachel Griffiths.

results.title: Say a little prayer
results.creator_credit: Jill Bilcock, Richard Lowenstein, Carol Hughes and Flying Films
results.brief_description: Richard Lowenstein’s film “Say a Little Prayer” is an under-rated Australian children’s film about a child’s perspective on the world which adults can enjoy. Eleven year old Seymour is bored during the school holidays, living with his fussy guardian in Richmond. His world changes when he meets the fabulous Angie, a young woman who treats him with respect and loving attention. They begin a friendship which is initially fun until Seymour comes to understand that his friend is a heroin user, and her life not as carefree and safe as he initially believed. Lowenstein’s gift for understanding the specificicities of subculture make this a moving film about families and contemporary dislocation. Sudi de Winter is excellent as Angie and Mickey Camilleri is the shy child Seymour. Co-stars Ben Mendelsohn. Based on Robin Klein’s novel “Came back to show you I could fly” with music by Not Drowning, Waving.

results.title: Gypsy
results.creator_credit: Orry-Kelly, Philip Anderson, Mervyn LeRoy and Warner Bros Pictures
results.brief_description: Gypsy Rose Lee, burlesque Queen of renown, was driven to stardom much less by her own ambition, than by the ruthless determination of her mother. As the stereotypical domineering “stage mother”, Rosalind Russell’s performance is superb, while Karl Malden as her long-suffering but loyal lover also gives a fine performance. While the references to striptease are undeniably fleeting, Natalie Wood as Gypsy Rose Lee is creditable, but it is her vulnerability rather than her sex appeal which comes to the fore. Stephen Sondheim’s lyrics and Julie Styne’s score makes this a musical delight.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Orry-Kelly, Philip Anderson, Mervyn LeRoy and Warner Bros Pictures

results.creator_credit: Jill Bilcock, P.J. Hogan, Jocelyn Moorhouse, Lynda House, Peter Szabo and Associates, Film Victoria and House and Moorhouse Films
results.brief_description: Muriel is a dag, an Abba maniac and an out of place girl who would give anything to be like her nasty friends. In her hunt to find Mr. Right in all the wrong places, Muriel takes a one-way ticket to freedom to find herself.

constellations_other.name: Jill Bilcock
constellations_other.description: An editor’s work often goes unnoticed, but their scene-stitching not only brings the director’s vision to life but sometimes steals the show. One of Australia’s greatest editors, Jill Bilcock, has shaped some of the country’s most memorable screen stories.

results.creator_credit_for_label: Jill Bilcock, P.J. Hogan, Jocelyn Moorhouse, Lynda House, Peter Szabo and Associates, Film Victoria and House and Moorhouse Films

Muriel is a dag, an Abba maniac and an out-of-place girl who would give anything to be like her nasty friends. In her hunt to find Mr. Right in all the wrong places, Muriel takes a one-way ticket to freedom to find herself. A bittersweet and much acclaimed film that touches on themes of self-respect, identity and friendship.

Toni Collette gives an inspired performance as Muriel and the supporting cast includes Bill Hunter, Sophie Lee, Jeanie Drynan and Rachel Griffiths.

results.title: The October man
results.creator_credit: Alan Jaggs, Roy Baker, Eric Ambler and Two Cities Films
results.brief_description: In this powerful thriller, John Mills plays a lonely man who is recovering from a nervous breakdown. Through mysterious circumstances, he is suspected of a local murder and his past only confirms everyone’s suspicion of his guilt. His only hope is to prove his innocence himself. This superbly crafted movie benefits from a strong central performance by John Mills. The script, by Eric Ambler, could be a model for many of today’s thriller writers. This is a classic British mystery that absolutely bristles with suspense.
